  16. (* NOTE: If this file is hashtbl.mli, do not edit it directly! Instead,
  17.    edit templates/hashtbl.template.mli and run tools/sync_stdlib_docs *)

  19. (** Hash tables and hash functions.

  21.    Hash tables are hashed association tables, with in-place modification.
  22.    Because most operations on a hash table modify their input, they're
  23.    more commonly used in imperative code. The lookup of the value associated
  24.    with a key (see {!find}, {!find_opt}) is normally very fast, often faster
  25.    than the equivalent lookup in {!Map}.

  27.    The functors {!Make} and {!MakeSeeded} can be used when
  28.    performance or flexibility are key.
  29.    The user provides custom equality and hash functions for the key type,
  30.    and obtains a custom hash table type for this particular type of key.

  32.    {b Warning} a hash table is only as good as the hash function. A bad hash
  33.    function will turn the table into a degenerate association list,
  34.    with linear time lookup instead of constant time lookup.

  36.    The polymorphic {!t} hash table is useful in simpler cases or
  37.    in interactive environments. It uses the polymorphic {!hash} function
  38.    defined in the OCaml runtime (at the time of writing, it's SipHash),
  39.    as well as the polymorphic equality [(=)].

  41.    See {{!examples} the examples section}.
  42. *)

  44. (** {b Unsynchronized accesses} *)

  46. [@@@alert unsynchronized_access
  47.     "Unsynchronized accesses to hash tables are a programming error."
  48. ]

  50. (**
  51.     Unsynchronized accesses to a hash table may lead to an invalid hash table
  52.     state. Thus, concurrent accesses to a hash tables must be synchronized
  53.     (for instance with a {!Mutex.t}).
  54. *)


  57. (** {1 Generic interface} *)


  60. ‌type (!'a, !'b) t
  61. (** The type of hash tables from type ['a] to type ['b]. *)

  63. ‌val create : ?random: (* thwart tools/sync_stdlib_docs *) bool ->
  64.              int -> ('a, 'b) t
  65. (** [Hashtbl.create n] creates a new, empty hash table, with
  66.    initial size [n].  For best results, [n] should be on the
  67.    order of the expected number of elements that will be in
  68.    the table.  The table grows as needed, so [n] is just an
  69.    initial guess.

  71.    The optional [~random] parameter (a boolean) controls whether
  72.    the internal organization of the hash table is randomized at each
  73.    execution of [Hashtbl.create] or deterministic over all executions.

  75.    A hash table that is created with [~random] set to [false] uses a
  76.    fixed hash function ({!hash}) to distribute keys among
  77.    buckets.  As a consequence, collisions between keys happen
  78.    deterministically.  In Web-facing applications or other
  79.    security-sensitive applications, the deterministic collision
  80.    patterns can be exploited by a malicious user to create a
  81.    denial-of-service attack: the attacker sends input crafted to
  82.    create many collisions in the table, slowing the application down.

  84.    A hash table that is created with [~random] set to [true] uses the seeded
  85.    hash function {!seeded_hash} with a seed that is randomly chosen at hash
  86.    table creation time.  In effect, the hash function used is randomly
  87.    selected among [2^{30}] different hash functions.  All these hash
  88.    functions have different collision patterns, rendering ineffective the
  89.    denial-of-service attack described above.  However, because of
  90.    randomization, enumerating all elements of the hash table using {!fold}
  91.    or {!iter} is no longer deterministic: elements are enumerated in
  92.    different orders at different runs of the program.

  94.    If no [~random] parameter is given, hash tables are created
  95.    in non-random mode by default.  This default can be changed
  96.    either programmatically by calling {!randomize} or by
  97.    setting the [R] flag in the [OCAMLRUNPARAM] environment variable.

  99.    @before 4.00 the [~random] parameter was not present and all
  100.    hash tables were created in non-randomized mode. *)

  102. ‌val clear : ('a, 'b) t -> unit
  103. (** Empty a hash table. Use [reset] instead of [clear] to shrink the
  104.     size of the bucket table to its initial size. *)

  106. ‌val reset : ('a, 'b) t -> unit
  107. (** Empty a hash table and shrink the size of the bucket table
  108.     to its initial size.
  109.     @since 4.00 *)

  111. ‌val copy : ('a, 'b) t -> ('a, 'b) t
  112. (** Return a copy of the given hashtable. *)

  114. ‌val add : ('a, 'b) t -> key:'a -> data:'b -> unit
  115. (** [Hashtbl.add tbl ~key ~data] adds a binding of [key] to [data]
  116.    in table [tbl].

  118.    {b Warning}: Previous bindings for [key] are not removed, but simply
  119.    hidden. That is, after performing {!remove}[ tbl key],
  120.    the previous binding for [key], if any, is restored.
  121.    (Same behavior as with association lists.)

  123.    If you desire the classic behavior of replacing elements,
  124.    see {!replace}. *)

  126. ‌val find : ('a, 'b) t -> 'a -> 'b
  127. (** [Hashtbl.find tbl x] returns the current binding of [x] in [tbl],
  128.    or raises [Not_found] if no such binding exists. *)

  130. ‌val find_opt : ('a, 'b) t -> 'a -> 'b option
  131. (** [Hashtbl.find_opt tbl x] returns the current binding of [x] in [tbl],
  132.     or [None] if no such binding exists.
  133.     @since 4.05 *)

  135. ‌val find_all : ('a, 'b) t -> 'a -> 'b list
  136. (** [Hashtbl.find_all tbl x] returns the list of all data
  137.    associated with [x] in [tbl].
  138.    The current binding is returned first, then the previous
  139.    bindings, in reverse order of introduction in the table. *)

  141. ‌val mem : ('a, 'b) t -> 'a -> bool
  142. (** [Hashtbl.mem tbl x] checks if [x] is bound in [tbl]. *)

  144. ‌val remove : ('a, 'b) t -> 'a -> unit
  145. (** [Hashtbl.remove tbl x] removes the current binding of [x] in [tbl],
  146.    restoring the previous binding if it exists.
  147.    It does nothing if [x] is not bound in [tbl]. *)

  149. ‌val replace : ('a, 'b) t -> key:'a -> data:'b -> unit
  150. (** [Hashtbl.replace tbl ~key ~data] replaces the current binding of [key]
  151.    in [tbl] by a binding of [key] to [data].  If [key] is unbound in [tbl],
  152.    a binding of [key] to [data] is added to [tbl].
  153.    This is functionally equivalent to {!remove}[ tbl key]
  154.    followed by {!add}[ tbl key data]. *)

  156. ‌val iter : f:(key:'a -> data:'b -> unit) -> ('a, 'b) t -> unit
  157. (** [Hashtbl.iter ~f tbl] applies [f] to all bindings in table [tbl].
  158.    [f] receives the key as first argument, and the associated value
  159.    as second argument. Each binding is presented exactly once to [f].

  161.    The order in which the bindings are passed to [f] is unspecified.
  162.    However, if the table contains several bindings for the same key,
  163.    they are passed to [f] in reverse order of introduction, that is,
  164.    the most recent binding is passed first.

  166.    If the hash table was created in non-randomized mode, the order
  167.    in which the bindings are enumerated is reproducible between
  168.    successive runs of the program, and even between minor versions
  169.    of OCaml.  For randomized hash tables, the order of enumeration
  170.    is entirely random.

  172.    The behavior is not specified if the hash table is modified
  173.    by [f] during the iteration.
  174. *)

  176. ‌val filter_map_inplace: f:(key:'a -> data:'b -> 'b option) -> ('a, 'b) t ->
  177.     unit
  178. (** [Hashtbl.filter_map_inplace ~f tbl] applies [f] to all bindings in
  179.     table [tbl] and update each binding depending on the result of
  180.     [f].  If [f] returns [None], the binding is discarded.  If it
  181.     returns [Some new_val], the binding is update to associate the key
  182.     to [new_val].

  184.     Other comments for {!iter} apply as well.
  185.     @since 4.03 *)

  187. ‌val fold :
  188.   f:(key:'a -> data:'b -> 'acc -> 'acc) -> ('a, 'b) t -> init:'acc -> 'acc
  189. (** [Hashtbl.fold ~f tbl ~init] computes
  190.    [(f kN dN ... (f k1 d1 init)...)],
  191.    where [k1 ... kN] are the keys of all bindings in [tbl],
  192.    and [d1 ... dN] are the associated values.
  193.    Each binding is presented exactly once to [f].

  195.    The order in which the bindings are passed to [f] is unspecified.
  196.    However, if the table contains several bindings for the same key,
  197.    they are passed to [f] in reverse order of introduction, that is,
  198.    the most recent binding is passed first.

  200.    If the hash table was created in non-randomized mode, the order
  201.    in which the bindings are enumerated is reproducible between
  202.    successive runs of the program, and even between minor versions
  203.    of OCaml.  For randomized hash tables, the order of enumeration
  204.    is entirely random.

  206.    The behavior is not specified if the hash table is modified
  207.    by [f] during the iteration.
  208. *)

  210. ‌val length : ('a, 'b) t -> int
  211. (** [Hashtbl.length tbl] returns the number of bindings in [tbl].
  212.    It takes constant time.  Multiple bindings are counted once each, so
  213.    [Hashtbl.length] gives the number of times [Hashtbl.iter] calls its
  214.    first argument. *)

  216. ‌val randomize : unit -> unit
  217. (** After a call to [Hashtbl.randomize()], hash tables are created in
  218.     randomized mode by default: {!create} returns randomized
  219.     hash tables, unless the [~random:false] optional parameter is given.
  220.     The same effect can be achieved by setting the [R] parameter in
  221.     the [OCAMLRUNPARAM] environment variable.

  223.     It is recommended that applications or Web frameworks that need to
  224.     protect themselves against the denial-of-service attack described
  225.     in {!create} call [Hashtbl.randomize()] at initialization
  226.     time before any domains are created.

  228.     Note that once [Hashtbl.randomize()] was called, there is no way
  229.     to revert to the non-randomized default behavior of {!create}.
  230.     This is intentional.  Non-randomized hash tables can still be
  231.     created using [Hashtbl.create ~random:false].

  233.     @since 4.00 *)

  235. ‌val is_randomized : unit -> bool
  236. (** Return [true] if the tables are currently created in randomized mode
  237.     by default, [false] otherwise.
  238.     @since 4.03 *)

  240. ‌val rebuild : ?random (* thwart tools/sync_stdlib_docs *) :bool ->
  241.     ('a, 'b) t -> ('a, 'b) t
  242. (** Return a copy of the given hashtable.  Unlike {!copy},
  243.     {!rebuild}[ h] re-hashes all the (key, value) entries of
  244.     the original table [h].  The returned hash table is randomized if
  245.     [h] was randomized, or the optional [random] parameter is true, or
  246.     if the default is to create randomized hash tables; see
  247.     {!create} for more information.

  249.     {!rebuild} can safely be used to import a hash table built
  250.     by an old version of the {!Hashtbl} module, then marshaled to
  251.     persistent storage.  After unmarshaling, apply {!rebuild}
  252.     to produce a hash table for the current version of the {!Hashtbl}
  253.     module.

  255.     @since 4.12 *)

  257. (** @since 4.00 *)
  258. ‌type statistics = {
  259.   num_bindings: int;
  260.     (** Number of bindings present in the table.
  261.         Same value as returned by {!length}. *)
  262.   num_buckets: int;
  263.     (** Number of buckets in the table. *)
  264.   max_bucket_length: int;
  265.     (** Maximal number of bindings per bucket. *)
  266.   bucket_histogram: int array
  267.     (** Histogram of bucket sizes.  This array [histo] has
  268.         length [max_bucket_length + 1].  The value of
  269.         [histo.(i)] is the number of buckets whose size is [i]. *)
  270. }

  272. ‌val stats : ('a, 'b) t -> statistics
  273. (** [Hashtbl.stats tbl] returns statistics about the table [tbl]:
  274.    number of buckets, size of the biggest bucket, distribution of
  275.    buckets by size.
  276.    @since 4.00 *)

  278. (** {1 Hash tables and Sequences} *)

  280. ‌val to_seq : ('a,'b) t -> ('a * 'b) Seq.t
  281. (** Iterate on the whole table.  The order in which the bindings
  282.     appear in the sequence is unspecified. However, if the table contains
  283.     several bindings for the same key, they appear in reversed order of
  284.     introduction, that is, the most recent binding appears first.

  286.     The behavior is not specified if the hash table is modified
  287.     during the iteration.

  289.     @since 4.07 *)

  291. ‌val to_seq_keys : ('a,_) t -> 'a Seq.t
  292. (** Same as [Seq.map fst (to_seq m)]
  293.     @since 4.07 *)

  295. ‌val to_seq_values : (_,'b) t -> 'b Seq.t
  296. (** Same as [Seq.map snd (to_seq m)]
  297.     @since 4.07 *)

  299. ‌val add_seq : ('a,'b) t -> ('a * 'b) Seq.t -> unit
  300. (** Add the given bindings to the table, using {!add}
  301.     @since 4.07 *)

  303. ‌val replace_seq : ('a,'b) t -> ('a * 'b) Seq.t -> unit
  304. (** Add the given bindings to the table, using {!replace}
  305.     @since 4.07 *)

  307. ‌val of_seq : ('a * 'b) Seq.t -> ('a, 'b) t
  308. (** Build a table from the given bindings. The bindings are added
  309.     in the same order they appear in the sequence, using {!replace_seq},
  310.     which means that if two pairs have the same key, only the latest one
  311.     will appear in the table.
  312.     @since 4.07 *)

  314. (** {1 Functorial interface} *)

  316. (** The functorial interface allows the use of specific comparison
  317.     and hash functions, either for performance/security concerns,
  318.     or because keys are not hashable/comparable with the polymorphic builtins.

  320.     For instance, one might want to specialize a table for integer keys:
  321.     {[
  322.       module IntHash =
  323.         struct
  324.           type t = int
  325.           let equal i j = i=j
  326.           let hash i = i land max_int
  327.         end

  329.       module IntHashtbl = Hashtbl.Make(IntHash)

  331.       let h = IntHashtbl.create 17 in
  332.       IntHashtbl.add h 12 "hello"
  333.     ]}

  335.     This creates a new module [IntHashtbl], with a new type ['a
  336.     IntHashtbl.t] of tables from [int] to ['a]. In this example, [h]
  337.     contains [string] values so its type is [string IntHashtbl.t].

  339.     Note that the new type ['a IntHashtbl.t] is not compatible with
  340.     the type [('a,'b) Hashtbl.t] of the generic interface. For
  341.     example, [Hashtbl.length h] would not type-check, you must use
  342.     [IntHashtbl.length].
  343. *)

  345. module type HashedType =
  346.   sig
  347.     type t
  348.     (** The type of the hashtable keys. *)

  350.     val equal : t -> t -> bool
  351.     (** The equality predicate used to compare keys. *)

  353.     val hash : t -> int
  354.       (** A hashing function on keys. It must be such that if two keys are
  355.           equal according to [equal], then they have identical hash values
  356.           as computed by [hash].
  357.           Examples: suitable ([equal], [hash]) pairs for arbitrary key
  358.           types include
  359. -         ([(=)], {!hash}) for comparing objects by structure
  360.               (provided objects do not contain floats)
  361. -         ([(fun x y -> compare x y = 0)], {!hash})
  362.               for comparing objects by structure
  363.               and handling {!Stdlib.nan} correctly
  364. -         ([(==)], {!hash}) for comparing objects by physical
  365.               equality (e.g. for mutable or cyclic objects). *)
  366.    end
  367. (** The input signature of the functor {!Make}. *)

  369. module type S =
  370.   sig
  371.     type key
  372.     type !'a t
  373.     val create : int -> 'a t
  374.     val clear : 'a t -> unit
  375.     val reset : 'a t -> unit (** @since 4.00 *)

  377.     val copy : 'a t -> 'a t
  378.     val add : 'a t -> key:key -> data:'a -> unit
  379.     val remove : 'a t -> key -> unit
  380.     val find : 'a t -> key -> 'a
  381.     val find_opt : 'a t -> key -> 'a option
  382.     (** @since 4.05 *)

  384.     val find_all : 'a t -> key -> 'a list
  385.     val replace : 'a t -> key:key -> data:'a -> unit
  386.     val mem : 'a t -> key -> bool
  387.     val iter : f:(key:key -> data:'a -> unit) -> 'a t -> unit
  388.     val filter_map_inplace: f:(key:key -> data:'a -> 'a option) -> 'a t ->
  389.       unit
  390.     (** @since 4.03 *)

  392.     val fold :
  393.       f:(key:key -> data:'a -> 'acc -> 'acc) -> 'a t -> init:'acc -> 'acc
  394.     val length : 'a t -> int
  395.     val stats: 'a t -> statistics (** @since 4.00 *)

  397.     val to_seq : 'a t -> (key * 'a) Seq.t
  398.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  400.     val to_seq_keys : _ t -> key Seq.t
  401.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  403.     val to_seq_values : 'a t -> 'a Seq.t
  404.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  406.     val add_seq : 'a t -> (key * 'a) Seq.t -> unit
  407.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  409.     val replace_seq : 'a t -> (key * 'a) Seq.t -> unit
  410.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  412.     val of_seq : (key * 'a) Seq.t -> 'a t
  413.     (** @since 4.07 *)
  414.   end
  415. (** The output signature of the functor {!Make}. *)

  417. module Make (H : HashedType) : S with type key = H.t
  418. (** Functor building an implementation of the hashtable structure.
  419.     The functor [Hashtbl.Make] returns a structure containing
  420.     a type [key] of keys and a type ['a t] of hash tables
  421.     associating data of type ['a] to keys of type [key].
  422.     The operations perform similarly to those of the generic
  423.     interface, but use the hashing and equality functions
  424.     specified in the functor argument [H] instead of generic
  425.     equality and hashing.  Since the hash function is not seeded,
  426.     the [create] operation of the result structure always returns
  427.     non-randomized hash tables. *)

  429. module type SeededHashedType =
  430.   sig
  431.     type t
  432.     (** The type of the hashtable keys. *)

  434.     val equal: t -> t -> bool
  435.     (** The equality predicate used to compare keys. *)

  437.     val seeded_hash: int -> t -> int
  438.       (** A seeded hashing function on keys.  The first argument is
  439.           the seed.  It must be the case that if [equal x y] is true,
  440.           then [seeded_hash seed x = seeded_hash seed y] for any value of
  441.           [seed].  A suitable choice for [seeded_hash] is the function
  442.           {!Hashtbl.seeded_hash} below. *)
  443.   end
  444. (** The input signature of the functor {!MakeSeeded}.
  445.     @since 4.00 *)

  447. module type SeededS =
  448.   sig
  449.     type key
  450.     type !'a t
  451.     val create : ?random (* thwart tools/sync_stdlib_docs *) :bool ->
  452.                  int -> 'a t
  453.     val clear : 'a t -> unit
  454.     val reset : 'a t -> unit
  455.     val copy : 'a t -> 'a t
  456.     val add : 'a t -> key:key -> data:'a -> unit
  457.     val remove : 'a t -> key -> unit
  458.     val find : 'a t -> key -> 'a
  459.     val find_opt : 'a t -> key -> 'a option (** @since 4.05 *)

  461.     val find_all : 'a t -> key -> 'a list
  462.     val replace : 'a t -> key:key -> data:'a -> unit
  463.     val mem : 'a t -> key -> bool
  464.     val iter : f:(key:key -> data:'a -> unit) -> 'a t -> unit
  465.     val filter_map_inplace: f:(key:key -> data:'a -> 'a option) -> 'a t ->
  466.       unit
  467.     (** @since 4.03 *)

  469.     val fold :
  470.       f:(key:key -> data:'a -> 'acc -> 'acc) -> 'a t -> init:'acc -> 'acc
  471.     val length : 'a t -> int
  472.     val stats: 'a t -> statistics

  474.     val to_seq : 'a t -> (key * 'a) Seq.t
  475.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  477.     val to_seq_keys : _ t -> key Seq.t
  478.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  480.     val to_seq_values : 'a t -> 'a Seq.t
  481.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  483.     val add_seq : 'a t -> (key * 'a) Seq.t -> unit
  484.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  486.     val replace_seq : 'a t -> (key * 'a) Seq.t -> unit
  487.     (** @since 4.07 *)

  489.     val of_seq : (key * 'a) Seq.t -> 'a t
  490.     (** @since 4.07 *)
  491.   end
  492. (** The output signature of the functor {!MakeSeeded}.
  493.     @since 4.00 *)

  495. module MakeSeeded (H : SeededHashedType) : SeededS with type key = H.t
  496. (** Functor building an implementation of the hashtable structure.
  497.     The functor [Hashtbl.MakeSeeded] returns a structure containing
  498.     a type [key] of keys and a type ['a t] of hash tables
  499.     associating data of type ['a] to keys of type [key].
  500.     The operations perform similarly to those of the generic
  501.     interface, but use the seeded hashing and equality functions
  502.     specified in the functor argument [H] instead of generic
  503.     equality and hashing.  The [create] operation of the
  504.     result structure supports the [~random] optional parameter
  505.     and returns randomized hash tables if [~random:true] is passed
  506.     or if randomization is globally on (see {!Hashtbl.randomize}).
  507.     @since 4.00 *)


  510. (** {1 The polymorphic hash functions} *)


  513. val hash : 'a -> int
  514. (** [Hashtbl.hash x] associates a nonnegative integer to any value of
  515.    any type. It is guaranteed that
  516.    if [x = y] or [Stdlib.compare x y = 0], then [hash x = hash y].
  517.    Moreover, [hash] always terminates, even on cyclic structures. *)

  519. val seeded_hash : int -> 'a -> int
  520. (** A variant of {!hash} that is further parameterized by
  521.    an integer seed.
  522.    @since 4.00 *)

  524. val hash_param : int -> int -> 'a -> int
  525. (** [Hashtbl.hash_param meaningful total x] computes a hash value for [x],
  526.    with the same properties as for [hash]. The two extra integer
  527.    parameters [meaningful] and [total] give more precise control over
  528.    hashing. Hashing performs a breadth-first, left-to-right traversal
  529.    of the structure [x], stopping after [meaningful] meaningful nodes
  530.    were encountered, or [total] nodes (meaningful or not) were
  531.    encountered.  If [total] as specified by the user exceeds a certain
  532.    value, currently 256, then it is capped to that value.
  533.    Meaningful nodes are: integers; floating-point
  534.    numbers; strings; characters; booleans; and constant
  535.    constructors. Larger values of [meaningful] and [total] means that
  536.    more nodes are taken into account to compute the final hash value,
  537.    and therefore collisions are less likely to happen.  However,
  538.    hashing takes longer. The parameters [meaningful] and [total]
  539.    govern the tradeoff between accuracy and speed.  As default
  540.    choices, {!hash} and {!seeded_hash} take
  541.    [meaningful = 10] and [total = 100]. *)

  543. val seeded_hash_param : int -> int -> int -> 'a -> int
  544. (** A variant of {!hash_param} that is further parameterized by
  545.    an integer seed.  Usage:
  546.    [Hashtbl.seeded_hash_param meaningful total seed x].
  547.    @since 4.00 *)

  549. (** {1:examples Examples}

  551.   {2 Basic Example}

  553.   {[
  554.     (* 0...99 *)
  555.     let seq = Seq.ints 0 |> Seq.take 100

  557.     (* build from Seq.t *)
  558.     # let tbl =
  559.         seq
  560.         |> Seq.map (fun x -> x, string_of_int x)
  561.         |> Hashtbl.of_seq
  562.     val tbl : (int, string) Hashtbl.t = <abstr>

  564.     # Hashtbl.length tbl
  565.     - : int = 100

  567.     # Hashtbl.find_opt tbl 32
  568.     - : string option = Some "32"

  570.     # Hashtbl.find_opt tbl 166
  571.     - : string option = None

  573.     # Hashtbl.replace tbl 166 "one six six"
  574.     - : unit = ()

  576.     # Hashtbl.find_opt tbl 166
  577.     - : string option = Some "one six six"

  579.     # Hashtbl.length tbl
  580.     - : int = 101
  581.     ]}


  584.   {2 Counting Elements}

  586.   Given a sequence of elements (here, a {!Seq.t}), we want to count how many
  587.   times each distinct element occurs in the sequence. A simple way to do this,
  588.   assuming the elements are comparable and hashable, is to use a hash table
  589.   that maps elements to their number of occurrences.

  591.   Here we illustrate that principle using a sequence of (ascii) characters
  592.   (type [char]).
  593.   We use a custom [Char_tbl] specialized for [char].

  595.   {[
  596.     # module Char_tbl = Hashtbl.Make(struct
  597.         type t = char
  598.         let equal = Char.equal
  599.         let hash = Hashtbl.hash
  600.       end)

  602.     (*  count distinct occurrences of chars in [seq] *)
  603.     # let count_chars (seq : char Seq.t) : _ list =
  604.         let counts = Char_tbl.create 16 in
  605.         Seq.iter
  606.           (fun c ->
  607.             let count_c =
  608.               Char_tbl.find_opt counts c
  609.               |> Option.value ~default:0
  610.             in
  611.             Char_tbl.replace counts c (count_c + 1))
  612.           seq;
  613.         (* turn into a list *)
  614.         Char_tbl.fold (fun c n l -> (c,n) :: l) counts []
  615.           |> List.sort (fun (c1,_)(c2,_) -> Char.compare c1 c2)
  616.     val count_chars : Char_tbl.key Seq.t -> (Char.t * int) list = <fun>

  618.     (* basic seq from a string *)
  619.     # let seq = String.to_seq "hello world, and all the camels in it!"
  620.     val seq : char Seq.t = <fun>

  622.     # count_chars seq
  623.     - : (Char.t * int) list =
  624.     [(' ', 7); ('!', 1); (',', 1); ('a', 3); ('c', 1); ('d', 2); ('e', 3);
  625.      ('h', 2); ('i', 2); ('l', 6); ('m', 1); ('n', 2); ('o', 2); ('r', 1);
  626.      ('s', 1); ('t', 2); ('w', 1)]

  628.     (* "abcabcabc..." *)
  629.     # let seq2 =
  630.         Seq.cycle (String.to_seq "abc") |> Seq.take 31
  631.     val seq2 : char Seq.t = <fun>

  633.     # String.of_seq seq2
  634.     - : String.t = "abcabcabcabcabcabcabcabcabcabca"

  636.     # count_chars seq2
  637.     - : (Char.t * int) list = [('a', 11); ('b', 10); ('c', 10)]

  639.   ]}

  641. *)

One Level Up Top Level
